rev.comment: + refs in the theft incident. changed title to "Malware and theft"
rev.diff:
Line 154: Line 154:
Although the default Bitcoin client is open source, some of its inner-workings are very difficult for independent programmers to review. Transactions are based on scripts that are contained inside the transactions and are to be executed to 'access the money'. While this increases flexibility of transactions, it does complicate the development of Bitcoin applications.<ref>{{cite web | url=https://forum.bitcoin.org/index.php?topic=4278.msg104751#msg104751 | title=What would you change about the Bitcoin protocol?|author=alkor}}</ref>
Although the default Bitcoin client is open source, some of its inner-workings are very difficult for independent programmers to review. Transactions are based on scripts that are contained inside the transactions and are to be executed to 'access the money'. While this increases flexibility of transactions, it does complicate the development of Bitcoin applications.<ref>{{cite web | url=https://forum.bitcoin.org/index.php?topic=4278.msg104751#msg104751 | title=What would you change about the Bitcoin protocol?|author=alkor}}</ref>
â
===Theft===
+
===Malware and theft===
â
Bitcoins can be stolen if a wallet file is left unprotected. On June 13, 2011, a bitcoin user who goes by the forum handle 'allinvain' allegedly had his computer compromised and 25,000 bitcoins stolen worth roughly $467,000 [[USD]]. The theft highlighted Malware designed specifically to steal BTC. <ref>[http://www.wired.co.uk/news/archive/2011-06/17/bitcoin-malware]</ref>. A short time after the theft, an account supposedly related to the group '[[lulzsec]]' received a 25,000 bitcoin 'donation' <ref>http://iwtf.net/2011/06/15/500k-bitcoin-theft/</ref>
+
A bitcoin account can be compromised if a wallet file is left unprotected. On June 13, 2011, a bitcoin user who goes by the forum handle 'allinvain' allegedly had his computer compromised and 25,000 bitcoins stolen worth roughly $467,000 [[USD]] at the time.<ref>http://forum.bitcoin.org/index.php?topic=16457.0</ref><ref>http://news.softpedia.com/news/Cyber-Theft-Incident-Shows-the-Other-Side-of-the-Bitcoin-206205.shtml</ref><ref>http://www.pcworld.com/article/230377/worlds_first_virtual_heist_bitcoin_user_loses_500000.html</ref> The theft highlighted Malware designed specifically to steal BTC. <ref>[http://www.wired.co.uk/news/archive/2011-06/17/bitcoin-malware]</ref>. A short time after the theft, an account supposedly related to the group '[[lulzsec]]' received a 25,000 bitcoin 'donation' <ref>http://iwtf.net/2011/06/15/500k-bitcoin-theft/</ref>
